summary: This document is an email chain between an Assistant U.S. Attorney and the chambers of Judge Sarah Netburn regarding the civil case Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al. It includes the submission of a letter with a pertinent legal decision as additional authority and a request for a Word version of a sealed order.

persons.name: Judge Sarah Netburn
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al.; her chambers are the recipient of the correspondence and she requested a Word version of a sealed order.

persons.name: Rachel
persons.context: Courtroom Deputy to Judge Sarah Netburn who sent an email requesting a Word version of a sealed order in the case.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: An unnamed Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York who is corresponding with Judge Netburn's chambers, providing additional legal authority and responding to requests related to the case.

connections.description: The Assistant U.S. Attorney is communicating with Judge Netburn's chambers regarding legal proceedings in the case Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al., submitting documents and responding to requests.
Rachel is identified as the Courtroom Deputy to Judge Sarah Netburn, acting on behalf of the judge's chambers in correspondence.

events.title: Submission of Additional Legal Authority
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney submits a letter with a recent pertinent legal decision to Judge Netburn's chambers in connection with the Government's application in the case Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al.

events.title: Request for Sealed Order
events.description: Rachel, on behalf of Judge Netburn, requests a Word version of a sealed order from the Assistant U.S. Attorney in the case Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al.

keyFacts: The document pertains to the civil case 'Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein, et al., 17 Civ. 616 (JGK)(SN)'.
An Assistant U.S. Attorney provided a letter with a recent pertinent legal decision as additional authority to Judge Sarah Netburn's chambers.
Judge Netburn's courtroom deputy, Rachel, requested a Word version of a sealed order from the Assistant U.S. Attorney.
The correspondence indicates ongoing legal proceedings and document exchanges between the U.S. Attorney's office and the court in this Epstein-related civil case.
